subject: history
title: Non-Cooperation-Khilafat Movement (1920-1922)
description: Gandhi's first all-India mass movement; peak of Hindu-Muslim unity

phases.name: Preparation & Launch
phases.description: From Khilafat delegation failure to formal launch

phases.name: Movement at Peak
phases.description: Mass participation; boycotts and hartals across India

phases.name: Suspension & Aftermath
phases.description: Chauri Chaura and Gandhi's decision to call off

events.title: Gandhi Proposes Non-Cooperation
events.description: After Khilafat delegation failure, Gandhi advocates non-cooperation

context: Khilafat delegation to England returned empty-handed (March 1920)
Hunter Committee report on Jallianwala Bagh unsatisfactory
gandhiProposal: Proposed non-violent non-cooperation with British government
Until three wrongs redressed: Khilafat wrong, Punjab wrong, Swaraj
Peaceful boycott of British institutions, goods, titles, services

resolution: Aims: Redress of Khilafat and Punjab wrongs; attainment of Swaraj
Methods: Boycott of legislatures, courts, schools, foreign cloth, titles
opposition: C.R. Das, Motilal Nehru initially opposed (later became supporters)
Feared loss of contact with masses if boycotted councils
details.gandhiPromise: 'Swaraj in one year' if program followed sincerely

events.title: Death of Bal Gangadhar Tilak
events.description: Tilak's death removes potential opposition to Gandhi

impact: His death left vacuum; Gandhi became undisputed leader
Symbolically ended extremist era; Gandhi era began
details.funeral: Largest funeral procession till then; 200,000+ attended

decisions: Congress goal changed from 'self-government within British Empire' to 'Swaraj' (complete self-rule)
Membership fee reduced to 4 annas (to enable poor to join)
Provincial Congress Committees (PCCs) organized on linguistic basis
opposition: Moderates like Jinnah, C.Y. Chintamani opposed
details.significance: Transformed Congress from elite body to mass organization; Gandhi's leadership established

firstStage.title: First Stage (Immediate)
actions: Surrender of titles, honors, honorary posts
Boycott of official functions and durbars
Withdrawal from nominated seats in local bodies
Refusal to attend government levees, parties

secondStage.title: Second Stage
actions: Boycott of legislative councils (Central and Provincial)
Boycott of law courts by lawyers and litigants
Boycott of government schools and colleges
Boycott of foreign cloth and goods; bonfire of foreign cloth

thirdStage.title: Third Stage (if needed)
actions: Mass civil disobedience including tax refusal
Resignation from government service (police, military, civil service)

events.title: Mass Surrender of Titles and Honors
events.description: Hundreds surrender British titles as protest

details.impact: Symbolic rejection of British honors; showed determination

events.title: Boycott of Prince of Wales Visit
events.description: Hartals and boycott during royal visit; some violence

visit: Prince of Wales (future King Edward VIII) visited India
Congress called for complete boycott (hartal, black flags)
bombayRiots: Communal riots between Hindus and Muslims
Gandhi fasted for 5 days as penance
details.significance: Successful boycott but violence worried Gandhi

scale: Thousands of students left government schools and colleges
Teachers also resigned in many cases
nationalInstitutions: National schools and colleges established as alternative
Taught in vernacular languages; nationalist curriculum
challenges: Lack of funds for national institutions
Many students returned to government schools after movement ended

events.title: Lawyers Boycott Courts
events.description: Prominent lawyers give up lucrative practice

prominentLawyers: C.R. Das (earning Rs 25,000/month, highest in Bengal)
Motilal Nehru (earning Rs 1,00,000/year, highest in UP)
details.sacrifice: Gave up highly lucrative practices; immense personal sacrifice
details.alternative: Panchayat courts and arbitration committees set up but not very successful
details.impact: Showed dedication; but most lawyers eventually returned to practice

events.title: Boycott & Bonfire of Foreign Cloth
events.description: Massive campaign against foreign cloth; charkha promoted

boycott: Public bonfires of foreign cloth across India
Picketing of shops selling foreign cloth
Imports of British cloth dropped dramatically (48% decline 1920-22)
khadi: Khadi (hand-spun cloth) became symbol of swadeshi and self-reliance
Gandhi wore only loincloth and shawl (from 1921) - symbol of poverty identification
All Congress members required to spin daily
economic: Benefited Indian handloom weavers and spinners
Lancashire mills protested to British government
details.symbolism: Charkha and khadi became symbols of self-reliance, nationalism, identification with poor

elections1920: Elections to provincial and central councils held under GOI Act 1919
In some provinces (Bengal, Bombay, Madras) 60-70% boycott
impact: Dyarchy couldn't function properly with empty councils
Those elected (mainly moderates and loyalists) had limited legitimacy
Showed mass support for Gandhi over moderates
details.laterDevelopment: After movement ended, Congress participated in 1923 elections (Swaraj Party formed)

events.title: Unprecedented Mass Participation
events.description: All sections of society joined movement

breadth: First truly mass movement in Indian history
Women came out in large numbers for first time
scale: Tilak Swaraj Fund: Rs 1 crore collected in few months
Millions participated in hartals and processions

arrests: Prominent leaders jailed: Ali Brothers (Sep 1921), C.R. Das, Lajpat Rai
repressiveMeasures: Heavy fines on towns and villages
details.gandhiStillFree: Gandhi not arrested yet; government feared making him martyr would escalate movement

events.title: Bardoli Resolution - Civil Disobedience Planned
events.description: Gandhi plans mass civil disobedience in Bardoli, Gujarat

decision: All-India Congress Committee met at Bardoli (Gujarat)
Decided to launch mass civil disobedience
Tax refusal and complete non-cooperation planned
details.timing: Civil disobedience to start within 7 days if demands not met
details.confidence: Movement at peak; success seemed near; 'Swaraj' appeared within reach

events.title: CHAURI CHAURA INCIDENT
events.description: Violent mob kills 22 policemen; Gandhi shocked

details.place: Chauri Chaura, Gorakhpur district, United Provinces (UP)
incident: Police tried to disperse; opened fire
gandhiReaction: Gandhi was in Bardoli planning mass civil disobedience
Believed people not ready for mass civil disobedience

events.title: Non-Cooperation Movement Suspended
events.description: Gandhi calls off entire movement; leaders shocked

decision: Congress Working Committee met at Bardoli (Feb 11-12)
reaction: Felt movement at peak; shouldn't stop
Jawaharlal Nehru, Subhash Bose, C.R. Das deeply upset
Felt one local incident shouldn't derail nationwide movement
Felt Gandhi abandoned struggle at crucial moment
gandhiLogic: 'Better to suspend movement than allow it to become violent'

events.title: Gandhi Arrested
events.description: After suspending movement, Gandhi arrested for sedition

arrest: Charged with sedition (for writings in 'Young India' magazine)
trial: Gave historic speech: 'Non-cooperation with evil is as much a duty as cooperation with good'
Judge: C.N. Broomfield (appreciated Gandhi but had to convict)
details.quote: Gandhi's statement: 'I am here to invite and submit cheerfully to the highest penalty that can be inflicted upon me for what in law is a deliberate crime and what appears to me to be the highest duty of a citizen'

events.title: Gandhi Released (Health Grounds)
events.description: Released after appendicitis operation; served only 2 years

aftermath: By time of release, political situation changed
Khilafat issue dead (Turkey abolished Caliphate March 1924)

assessment.title: Assessment of Non-Cooperation Movement
achievements: First all-India mass movement; millions participated
Demonstrated power of non-violent mass resistance
Transformed Congress from elite club to mass organization
British imports declined drastically (48% drop in cloth)
Khadi and charkha became symbols of nationalism
Women participated in large numbers for first time
Showed British rule rested on Indian cooperation; withdrawal could paralyze system
limitations: Did not achieve Swaraj (Gandhi's promise failed)
Constructive program (national schools, etc.) couldn't sustain
Lawyers, students mostly returned to old careers
Primarily middle-class movement; limited peasant participation

gandhiDefense: Non-violence was fundamental principle, not tactic
Movement becoming violent; had to stop
Better to suspend than let it degenerate
Moral authority came from non-violence; violence would delegitimize
critics: One local incident shouldn't derail nationwide movement
Movement at peak; victory within reach
Gandhi's personal morality imposed on political movement
Betrayed those who sacrificed (jailed, lost careers)

aftermath: Swaraj Party formed (1923) for council entry
Next major movement only in 1930 (Civil Disobedience)
significance: Despite suspension, permanently changed Indian politics
British realized they ruled on sufferance

mustRemember: Three aims: Khilafat wrong, Punjab wrong, Swaraj
Methods: Boycott of councils, courts, schools, foreign cloth, titles
Constructive: Khadi, national schools, Hindu-Muslim unity
Peak Hindu-Muslim unity; Ali Brothers and Gandhi together
Chauri Chaura incident: February 4, 1922 (22 policemen killed)
First mass movement; millions participated; transformed Congress
